{{short description|Sea water particles that are formed directly from the ocean}} [[File:Sea spray and waves (Unsplash).jpg|thumb|300px|Sea spray generated by breaking surface waves]]
'''Sea spray''' refers to [[aerosol]] particles that are formed directly from the [[ocean]], mostly by ejection into the atmosphere by bursting bubbles at the air-sea interface<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/1039150843|title=Sea salt aerosol production : mechanisms, methods, measurements and models : a critical review|last=E.|first=Lewis, Ernie R. VerfasserIn. Schwartz, Stephen|date=2010|publisher=American Geophysical Union|isbn=9781118666050|oclc=1039150843}}</ref>. Sea spray contains both organic matter and inorganic salts that form [[sea salt aerosol]] (SSA)<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gantt|first1=Brett|last2=Meskhidze|first2=Nicholas|date=2013|title=The physical and chemical characteristics of marine primary organic aerosol: a review|url=http://www.atmos-chem-phys.net/13/3979/2013/acp-13-3979-2013.html|journal=Atmospheric Chemistry and Physics|volume=13|issue=8|pages=3979–3996|bibcode=2013ACP....13.3979G|doi=10.5194/acp-13-3979-2013}}</ref>. SSA has the ability to form [[cloud condensation nuclei]] (CCN) and remove anthropogenic aerosol pollutants from the atmosphere<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rosenfeld|first=Daniel|last2=Lahav|first2=Ronen|last3=Khain|first3=Alexander|last4=Pinsky|first4=Mark|date=2002-09-06|title=The Role of Sea Spray in Cleansing Air Pollution over Ocean via Cloud Processes|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/297/5587/1667|journal=Science|language=en|volume=297|issue=5587|pages=1667–1670|doi=10.1126/science.1073869|issn=0036-8075|pmid=12183635}}</ref>. Sea spray is directly (and indirectly, through SSA) responsible for a significant degree of the heat and moisture fluxes between the atmosphere and the ocean<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Andreas|first=Edgar L|last2=Edson|first2=James B.|last3=Monahan|first3=Edward C.|last4=Rouault|first4=Mathieu P.|last5=Smith|first5=Stuart D.|date=1995|title=The spray contribution to net evaporation from the sea: A review of recent progress|url=https://doi.org/10.1007/BF00712389|journal=Boundary-Layer Meteorology|language=en|volume=72|issue=1-2|pages=3–52|doi=10.1007/bf00712389|issn=0006-8314}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Andreas|first=Edgar L|date=1992|title=Sea Spray and the Turbulent Air-Sea Heat Fluxes|url=https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1029/92JC00876|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research|language=en|volume=97|issue=C7|pages=11429–11441|doi=10.1029/92jc00876|issn=0148-0227}}</ref>, affecting global climate patterns and tropical storm intensity<ref>{{Cite journal|title=https://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/abs/10.1175/1520-0469(2001)058%3C3741:EOSSOT%3E2.0.CO;2|url=https://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/abs/10.1175/1520-0469(2001)058%3C3741:EOSSOT%3E2.0.CO;2|language=en|doi=10.1175/1520-0469(2001)058%3C3741:eossot%3E2.0.co;2}}</ref>.Sea spray also influences plant growth and species distribution in coastal ecosystems<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Malloch|first=A. J. C.|date=1972|title=Salt-Spray Deposition on the Maritime Cliffs of the Lizard Peninsula|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/2258044|journal=Journal of Ecology|volume=60|issue=1|pages=103–112|doi=10.2307/2258044}}</ref> and increases corrosion of building materials in coastal areas<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schindelholz|first=E.|last2=Risteen|first2=B. E.|last3=Kelly|first3=R. G.|date=2014-01-01|title=Effect of Relative Humidity on Corrosion of Steel under Sea Salt Aerosol Proxies I. NaCl|url=http://jes.ecsdl.org/content/161/10/C450|journal=Journal of The Electrochemical Society|language=en|volume=161|issue=10|pages=C450–C459|doi=10.1149/2.0221410jes|issn=0013-4651}}</ref>.
== Generation == [[File:Sea spray sea foam connection.png|thumb|500px| {{center|Connection between [[sea foam]] and sea spray formation. The dark orange line indicates processes common to the formation of both sea spray and sea foam.}}]]
=== Formation === When wind, whitecaps, and breaking waves mix air into the sea surface, the air regroups to form bubbles, floats to the surface, and bursts at the air-sea interface <ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=de Leeuw|first=Gerrit|last2=Andreas|first2=Edgar L|last3=Anguelova|first3=Magdalena D.|last4=Fairall|first4=C. W.|last5=Lewis|first5=Ernie R.|last6=O'Dowd|first6=Colin|last7=Schulz|first7=Michael|last8=Schwartz|first8=Stephen E.|date=2011-05-07|title=Production flux of sea spray aerosol|url=https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1029/2010RG000349|journal=Reviews of Geophysics|language=en|volume=49|issue=2|doi=10.1029/2010rg000349|issn=8755-1209}}</ref>. When they burst, they release up to a thousand particles of sea spray <ref name=":2" /> <ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Veron|first=Fabrice|date=2015-01-03|title=Ocean Spray|url=https://www.annualreviews.org/doi/10.1146/annurev-fluid-010814-014651|journal=Annual Review of Fluid Mechanics|language=en|volume=47|issue=1|pages=507–538|doi=10.1146/annurev-fluid-010814-014651|issn=0066-4189}}</ref>, which range in size from nanometers to micrometers and can be expelled up to 20 cm from the sea surface <ref name=":2" />. '''Film droplets''' make up the majority of the smaller particles created by the initial burst, while '''jet droplets''' are generated by a collapse of the bubble cavity and are ejected from the sea surface in the form of a vertical jet <ref>{{Cite journal|last=MacIntyre|first=Ferren|date=1972-09-20|title=Flow patterns in breaking bubbles|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1029/jc077i027p05211|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research|volume=77|issue=27|pages=5211–5228|doi=10.1029/jc077i027p05211|issn=0148-0227}}</ref><ref name=":0" />. In windy conditions, water droplets are mechanically torn off from crests of breaking waves. Sea spray droplets generated via such a mechanism are called '''spume droplets''' ''<ref name=":0" />'' and are typically larger in size and have less residence time in air. Impingement of plunging waves on sea surface also generates sea spray in the form of '''splash droplets''' <ref name=":0" />''<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Andreas|first=Edgar L.|date=2002-09-30|title=The Impact of Sea Spray on Air-Sea Fluxes in Coupled Atmosphere-Ocean Models|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.21236/ada627095|location=Fort Belvoir, VA}}</ref>''. The composition of the sea spray depends primarily on the composition of the water from which it is produced, but broadly speaking is a mixture of salts and [[organic matter]]. Several factors determine the production flux of sea spray, especially wind speed, [[Swell (ocean)|swell]] height, swell period, humidity, and temperature differential between the atmosphere and the surface water <ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=de Leeuw|first=Gerrit|last2=Neele|first2=Filip P.|last3=Hill|first3=Martin|last4=Smith|first4=Michael H.|last5=Vignati|first5=Elisabetta|date=2000-12-01|title=Production of sea spray aerosol in the surf zone|url=https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1029/2000JD900549|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres|language=en|volume=105|issue=D24|pages=29397–29409|doi=10.1029/2000jd900549|issn=0148-0227}}</ref>. Production and size distribution rate of SSAs are thus sensitive to the mixing state <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Prather|first=Kimberly A.|last2=Bertram|first2=Timothy H.|last3=Grassian|first3=Vicki H.|last4=Deane|first4=Grant B.|last5=Stokes|first5=M. Dale|last6=DeMott|first6=Paul J.|last7=Aluwihare|first7=Lihini I.|last8=Palenik|first8=Brian P.|last9=Azam|first9=Farooq|date=2013-05-07|title=Bringing the ocean into the laboratory to probe the chemical complexity of sea spray aerosol|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/110/19/7550|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|language=en|volume=110|issue=19|pages=7550–7555|doi=10.1073/pnas.1300262110|issn=0027-8424|pmid=23620519}}</ref>. A lesser studied area of sea spray generation is the formation of sea spray as a result of rain drop impact on the sea surface ''<ref name=":0" />.
=== Spatial variation === In addition to the local conditions that influence sea spray formation, there are also consistent spatial patterns in sea spray production and composition. Because sea spray is generated when air is mixed into the ocean, formation gradients are established by [[turbulence]] of the surface water <ref name=":3" />. Wave action along coastal shorelines is generally where turbulence is greatest, so this is where sea spray production is the highest. Particles generated in turbulent coastal areas can travel horizontally up to 25 km within the [[planetary boundary layer]] <ref name=":3" />. As distance from shore decreases, sea spray production declines to a level sustained almost exclusively by white caps <ref name=":3" />. The proportion of the ocean surface area that is turbulent enough to produce significant sea spray is called the white cap fraction <ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=de Leeuw|first=Gerrit|last2=Andreas|first2=Edgar L|last3=Anguelova|first3=Magdalena D.|last4=Fairall|first4=C. W.|last5=Lewis|first5=Ernie R.|last6=O'Dowd|first6=Colin|last7=Schulz|first7=Michael|last8=Schwartz|first8=Stephen E.|date=2011-05-07|title=Production flux of sea spray aerosol|url=https://doi.org/10.1029/2010RG000349|journal=Reviews of Geophysics|language=en|volume=49|issue=2|doi=10.1029/2010rg000349|issn=8755-1209}}</ref>. The only other production mechanism of sea spray in the open ocean is through direct wind action, where strong winds actually break the surface tension of the water and lift particles into the air <ref name=":4" />. However, particles of seawater generated in this way are often too heavy to remain suspended in the atmosphere and usually are deposited back to the sea within a few dozen meters of transport <ref name=":4" />.
===Temporal variation === During winter months, the ocean typically experiences stormy, windy conditions that generate more air inundation into the sea and therefore more sea spray <ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=O'Dowd|first=Colin D.|last2=Langmann|first2=Baerbel|last3=Varghese|first3=Saji|last4=Scannell|first4=Claire|last5=Ceburnis|first5=Darius|last6=Facchini|first6=Maria Cristina|date=2008-01-01|title=A combined organic-inorganic sea-spray source function|url=https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1029/2007GL030331|journal=Geophysical Research Letters|language=en|volume=35|issue=1|doi=10.1029/2007gl030331|issn=0094-8276}}</ref>. Calmer summer months result in lower overall production of sea spray <ref name=":5" />. During peak [[Primary production|primary productivity]] in the summer, increased organic matter in the surface ocean drives subsequent increases in sea spray. Given that sea spray retains the properties of the water from which it was produced, the composition of sea spray experiences extreme seasonal variation. During the summer, dissolved organic carbon (DOC) can constitute 60-90% of sea spray mass <ref name=":5" />. Even though much more sea spray is produced during the stormy winter season, the composition is nearly all salt because of the low primary production <ref name=":5" />.
=== Organic matter === The organic matter in sea spray consists of [[Dissolved organic matter|dissolved organic carbon]]<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Russell|first1=L.M.|last2=Hawkins|first2=L.N.|last3=Frossard|first3=A.A.|last4=Quinn|first4=P.K.|last5=Bates|first5=T.S.|date=2010|title=Carbohydrate-like composition of submicron atmospheric particles and their production from ocean bubble bursting|journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA|volume=107|issue=15|pages=6652–6657|bibcode=2010PNAS..107.6652R|doi=10.1073/pnas.0908905107|pmc=2872374|pmid=20080571}}</ref> (DOC) and even microbes themselves, like bacteria and viruses.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Blanchard|first1=D.C.|last2=Syzdek|first2=L.D.|date=1972|title=Concentration of Bacteria in Jet Drops from Bursting Bubbles|journal=J. Geophys. Res.|volume=77|issue=27|pages=5087|bibcode=1972JGR....77.5087B|doi=10.1029/jc077i027p05087}}</ref> The amount of organic matter in sea spray depends on microbiological processes<ref>{{cite journal|last1=O'Dowd|first1=C.D.|last2=Facchini|first2=M.C.|last3=Cavalli|first3=F.|last4=Ceburnis|first4=D.|last5=Mircea|first5=M.|last6=Decesari|first6=S.|last7=Fuzzi|first7=S.|last8=Yoon|first8=Y.J.|last9=Putaud|first9=J.P.|date=2004|title=Biogenically driven organic contribution to marine aerosol|journal=Nature|volume=431|issue=7009|pages=676–680|bibcode=2004Natur.431..676O|doi=10.1038/nature02959|pmid=15470425}}</ref>, though the total effect of these processes is still unknown <ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Clayton|first=James L.|date=1972|title=Salt Spray and Mineral Cycling in Two California Coastal Ecosystems|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/1935711|journal=Ecology|volume=53|issue=1|pages=74–81|doi=10.2307/1935711}}</ref> <ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Quinn|first=Patricia K.|last2=Bates|first2=Timothy S.|last3=Schulz|first3=Kristen S.|last4=Coffman|first4=D. J.|last5=Frossard|first5=A. A.|last6=Russell|first6=L. M.|last7=Keene|first7=W. C.|last8=Kieber|first8=D. J.|date=2014-03|title=Contribution of sea surface carbon pool to organic matter enrichment in sea spray aerosol|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/ngeo2092|journal=Nature Geoscience|language=En|volume=7|issue=3|pages=228–232|doi=10.1038/ngeo2092|issn=1752-0894}}</ref>. Biomass often enters sea spray through the death and [[lysis]] of algal cells, often caused by [[Viral Infections|viral infections]] <ref name=":6" />. Cells are broken apart into DOC that is propelled into the atmosphere when surface bubbles pop. When primary productivity peaks during the summer, [[Algal bloom|algal blooms]] can generate an enormous amount of organic matter that is eventually incorporated into sea spray <ref name=":5" /> <ref name=":6" />. In the right conditions, aggregation of the DOC can also form [[surfactant]] or [[sea foam]].
[[Chlorophyll a|Chlorophyll-a]], which is used as a proxy for [[primary production]] in the [[photic zone]] of the ocean, is viewed by some researchers as a way to approximate the amount of organic matter present in sea spray. However, one study suggests that measurements of Chlorophyll-a and organic matter content in sea spray are only weakly correlated and that Chlorophyll-a is not an adequate proxy <ref name=":7" />.
== Climate interactions == At high winds the droplet evaporation layer (DEL) influences the surface energy heat exchange of the ocean <ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Andreas|first=Edgar L|last2=Edson|first2=James B.|last3=Monahan|first3=Edward C.|last4=Rouault|first4=Mathieu P.|last5=Smith|first5=Stuart D.|title=The spray contribution to net evaporation from the sea: A review of recent progress|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF00712389#citeas|journal=Boundary-Layer Meteorology|language=en|volume=72|issue=1-2|doi=10.1007/bf00712389#citeas|issn=0006-8314}}</ref>. The [[latent heat flux]] of sea spray generated at the DEL has been cited as an important addition to climate modeling efforts, particularly in simulations assessing air/sea heat balance as related to hurricanes and cyclones formed during high wind events <ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Andreas|first=Edgar L|date=1992|title=Sea Spray and the Turbulent Air-Sea Heat Fluxes|url=https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1029/92JC00876|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research|language=en|volume=97|issue=C7|pages=11429–11441|doi=10.1029/92jc00876|issn=0148-0227}}</ref>. During the formation of whitecaps, sea spray droplets exhibit the same properties as the ocean surface, but rapidly adapt to surrounding air. Some sea spray droplets immediately reabsorb into the sea while others evaporate entirely and contribute salt particles like [[dimethyl sulfide]] (DMS) to the atmosphere where they can be transported via turbulence to cloud layers and serve as CCN <ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Prather|first=Kimberly A.|last2=Bertram|first2=Timothy H.|last3=Grassian|first3=Vicki H.|last4=Deane|first4=Grant B.|last5=Stokes|first5=M. Dale|last6=DeMott|first6=Paul J.|last7=Aluwihare|first7=Lihini I.|last8=Palenik|first8=Brian P.|last9=Azam|first9=Farooq|date=2013-05-07|title=Bringing the ocean into the laboratory to probe the chemical complexity of sea spray aerosol|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/110/19/7550|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|language=en|volume=110|issue=19|pages=7550–7555|doi=10.1073/pnas.1300262110|issn=0027-8424|pmid=23620519}}</ref>. The formation of these CCN like DMS have climate implications as well, due to their influence on cloud formation and interaction with solar radiation <ref name=":9" />. Additionally, the contribution of sea spray DMS to the atmosphere is linked to the global [[sulfur cycle]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Eriksson|first=Erik|date=1963-07-01|title=The yearly circulation of sulfur in nature|url=https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/epdf/10.1029/JZ068i013p04001|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research|language=en|volume=68|issue=13|pages=4001–4008|doi=10.1029/jz068i013p04001|issn=0148-0227}}</ref>. Understanding total forcing from natural sources like sea spray can illuminate critical constraints posed by [[Anthropogenic effect|anthropogenic]] influence and can be coupled with ocean chemistry, biology and physics to predict future ocean and atmospheric variability <ref name=":9" />.
The proportion of organic matter in sea spray can impact [[reflectance]], determine the overall cooling effect of SSAs <ref name=":6" />, and slightly alter the capacity for SSAs to form CCN (17). Even small changes in SSA levels can affect the global radiation budget leading to implications for global climate <ref name=":6" />. SSA has a low [[albedo]], but its presence overlaid on the darker ocean surface affects absorption and reflectance of incoming solar radiation <ref name=":6" />.
=== Enthalpy flux === The influence of sea spray on the surface heat and moisture exchange peaks during times of greatest difference between air and sea temperatures <ref name=":8" />. When air temperature is low, sea spray [[sensible heat flux]] can be nearly as great as the spray latent heat flux at high latitudes <ref name=":10" />. In addition, sea spray enhances the air/sea enthalpy flux during high winds as a result of temperature and humidity redistribution in the [[Surface layer|marine boundary layer]] <ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|title=https://doi.org/10.1175/1520-0469(2001)058%3C3741:EOSSOT%3E2.0.CO;2|url=https://doi.org/10.1175/1520-0469(2001)058%3C3741:EOSSOT%3E2.0.CO;2|language=en|doi=10.1175/1520-0469(2001)058%3C3741:eossot%3E2.0.co;2}}</ref>. Sea spray droplets injected into the air thermally equilibrate ~1% of their mass. This leads to the addition of sensible heat prior to ocean reentry, enhancing their potential for significant enthalpy input <ref name=":11" />.
===Dynamic effects=== The effects of sea spray transport in the [[atmospheric boundary layer]] is not yet completely understood'' <ref name=":0" />''. Sea spray droplets alter the air-sea momentum fluxes by being accelerated and decelerated by the winds'' <ref name=":0" />''. In hurricane-force winds, it is observed that there is some reduction in the air/sea momentum flux'' <ref name=":2" />''. This reduction in momentum flux manifests as saturation of air/sea [[drag coefficient]]. Some studies have identified spray effects as one of the potential reasons for the air/sea drag coefficient saturation <ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Bell|first=Michael M.|last2=Montgomery|first2=Michael T.|last3=Emanuel|first3=Kerry A.|date=2012-11|title=Air–Sea Enthalpy and Momentum Exchange at Major Hurricane Wind Speeds Observed during CBLAST|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1175/jas-d-11-0276.1|journal=Journal of the Atmospheric Sciences|volume=69|issue=11|pages=3197–3222|doi=10.1175/jas-d-11-0276.1|issn=0022-4928}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Donelan|first=M. A.|date=2004|title=On the limiting aerodynamic roughness of the ocean in very strong winds|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1029/2004gl019460|journal=Geophysical Research Letters|volume=31|issue=18|doi=10.1029/2004gl019460|issn=0094-8276}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Powell|first=Mark D.|last2=Vickery|first2=Peter J.|last3=Reinhold|first3=Timothy A.|date=2003-03|title=Reduced drag coefficient for high wind speeds in tropical cyclones|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nature01481|journal=Nature|volume=422|issue=6929|pages=279–283|doi=10.1038/nature01481|issn=0028-0836}}</ref>. It has been shown through several numerical and theoretical studies that sea spray, if present in significant amounts in the atmospheric boundary layer, leads to saturation of air-sea drag coefficients <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bye|first=John A. T.|last2=Jenkins|first2=Alastair D.|date=2006|title=Drag coefficient reduction at very high wind speeds|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1029/2005jc003114|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research|volume=111|issue=C3|doi=10.1029/2005jc003114|issn=0148-0227}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Liu|first=Bin|last2=Guan|first2=Changlong|last3=Xie|first3=Lian|date=2012-07-03|title=The wave state and sea spray related parameterization of wind stress applicable from low to extreme winds|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1029/2011jc007786|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research: Oceans|volume=117|issue=C11|pages=n/a–n/a|doi=10.1029/2011jc007786|issn=0148-0227}}</ref>.
== Ecology == === Coastal ecosystems === Salt deposition from sea spray is the primary factor influencing distribution of plant communities in coastal ecosystems <ref>{{Cite journal|last=MALLOCH|first=A. J. C.|date=1971-11|title=VEGETATION OF THE MARITIME CLIFF-TOPS OF THE LIZARD AND LAND'S END PENINSULAS, WEST CORNWALL|url=https://nph.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/epdf/10.1111/j.1469-8137.1971.tb04597.x|journal=New Phytologist|language=en|volume=70|issue=6|pages=1155–1197|doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.1971.tb04597.x|issn=0028-646X}}</ref>. Ion concentrations of sea spray deposited on land generally mirror their concentrations in the ocean, except that potassium is often higher in sea spray <ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=Malloch|first=A. J. C.|date=1972|title=Salt-Spray Deposition on the Maritime Cliffs of the Lizard Peninsula|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/2258044|journal=Journal of Ecology|volume=60|issue=1|pages=103–112|doi=10.2307/2258044}}</ref>. Deposition of salts on land generally decreases with distance from the ocean but increases with increasing wind speed <ref name=":12" />. Salt deposition from sea spray is correlated with a decrease in plant height and significant scarring, shoot reduction, stem height decrease, and tissue death on the windward side of shrubs and trees <ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Goldsmith|first=F. B.|date=1973|title=The Vegetation of Exposed Sea Cliffs at South Stack, Anglesey: II. Experimental Studies|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/2258652|journal=Journal of Ecology|volume=61|issue=3|pages=819–829|doi=10.2307/2258652}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/23928269|title=Some aspects of the vegetation of sea cliffs|last=B.|first=Goldsmith, F.|date=1967|oclc=23928269}}</ref>. Variation in salt deposition also influences competition between plants and establishes gradients of salt tolerance <ref name=":13" />.
While the salts within sea spray can severely inhibit plant growth in coastal ecosystems, selecting for salt-tolerant species, sea spray can also bring vital nutrients to these habitats. For example, one study showed that sea spray in Wales, UK delivers roughly 32 kg of potassium per hectare to coastal sand dunes each year <ref name=":4" />. Because dune soils leach nutrients very quickly, sea spray fertilization could be very influential to dune ecosystems, especially for plants that are less competitive in nutrient-limited environments.
[[File:Ocean mist and spray 2.jpg|thumb|left| Sea spray containing [[marine microorganism]]s can be swept high into the atmosphere. These airborne microorganisms may travel the globe before falling back to earth.]]
=== Microbial communities === Viruses, bacteria, and plankton are ubiquitous in sea water, and this biodiversity is reflected in the composition of sea spray <ref name=":3" />. Generally speaking, sea spray has slightly lower concentrations of microbes than the water it is produced from. However, the microbial community in sea spray is often distinct from nearby water and sandy beaches, suggesting that some species are more biased towards SSA transportation than others. Sea spray from one beach can contain thousands of [[Operational taxonomic unit|operational taxonomic units]] (OTUs)<ref name=":3" />. Nearly 10,000 different OTUs have been discovered in sea spray just between San Francisco, CA and Monterey, CA, with only 11% of them found ubiquitously <ref name=":3" />. This suggests that sea spray in every coastal region likely has its own unique assemblage of microbial diversity, with thousands of new OTUs yet to be discovered. Many of the more common OTUs have been identified to the following taxa: Cryptophyta (order), Stramenopiles (order) and OM60 (family)<ref name=":3" />. Many have even been identified to genus: Persicirhabdus, Fluviicola, Synecococcus, Vibrio, and Enterococcus <ref name=":3" />.
Scientists have conjectured a stream of airborne microorganisms circles the planet above weather systems but below commercial air lanes.<ref>[https://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/living-bacteria-are-riding-earths-air-currents-180957734/ Living Bacteria Are Riding Earth’s Air Currents] ''Smithsonian Magazine'', 11 January 2016.</ref> Some of these peripatetic microorganisms are swept up from terrestrial dust storms, but most originate from the marine microorganisms in sea spray. In 2018 a team of scientists reported that hundreds of millions of viruses and tens of millions of bacteria are deposited daily on every square meter around the planet.<ref>{{cite news |last=Robbins |first=Jim |title=Trillions Upon Trillions of Viruses Fall From the Sky Each Day |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/13/science/virosphere-evolution.html |date=13 April 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=14 April 2018 }}</ref><ref name="ISME-2018">{{cite journal |author1=Reche |first1=Isabel |last2=D’Orta |first2=Gaetano |last3=Mladenov |first3=Natalie |last4=Winget |first4= Danielle M |last5=Suttle |first5= Curtis A |title=Deposition rates of viruses and bacteria above the atmospheric boundary layer |journal=ISME Journal |url=https://www.nature.com/articles/s41396-017-0042-4.epdf |date=29 January 2018 |doi=10.1038/s41396-017-0042-4 |accessdate=14 April 2018 }}</ref>
== Chemical resistance == Sea spray is largely responsible for [[corrosion]] of metallic objects near the coastline, as the salts accelerate the corrosion process in the presence of abundant atmospheric [[oxygen]] and moisture<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Schindelholz|first=E.|last2=Risteen|first2=B. E.|last3=Kelly|first3=R. G.|date=2014-01-01|title=Effect of Relative Humidity on Corrosion of Steel under Sea Salt Aerosol Proxies I. NaCl|url=http://jes.ecsdl.org/content/161/10/C450|journal=Journal of The Electrochemical Society|language=en|volume=161|issue=10|pages=C450–C459|doi=10.1149/2.0221410jes|issn=0013-4651}}</ref>. Salts do not dissolve in air directly, but are suspended as fine [[particulates]], or dissolved in microscopic airborne water droplets<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Blanchard|first=Duncan C.|last2=Woodcock|first2=Alfred H.|date=1980-05|title=THE PRODUCTION, CONCENTRATION, AND VERTICAL DISTRIBUTION OF THE SEA-SALT AEROSOL|url=https://nyaspubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/j.1749-6632.1980.tb17130.x|journal=Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences|language=en|volume=338|issue=1 Aerosols|pages=330–347|doi=10.1111/j.1749-6632.1980.tb17130.x|issn=0077-8923}}</ref>.
The [[salt spray test]] is a measure of material endurance or resistance to corrosion, particularly if the material will be used outdoors and must perform in a [[Bearing (mechanical)|mechanical load bearing]] or otherwise critical role. These results are often of great interest to [[Marine industry|marine industries]], whose products may suffer extreme acceleration of corrosion and subsequent failure due to salt water exposure<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2007-10-01|title=Corrosion resistance of sintered duplex stainless steels in the salt fog spray test|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0924013607003718|journal=Journal of Materials Processing Technology|language=en|volume=192-193|pages=443–448|doi=10.1016/j.jmatprotec.2007.04.077|issn=0924-0136}}</ref>.

A Woman in the RCMP | image = The Red Wall book cover.jpg | caption = First edition cover of Canadian release | author = Jane Hall | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = Canada | subject = [[Women's rights]] | genre = [[Non-fiction]], bookGoodreads, [http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/2120062.The_red_wall ''The Red Wall''], Book review, Retrieved 11/23/2012 | publisher = General Store Publishing | pub_date = July 20, 2007 | media_type = Print (Paperback), eBook (EPUB, Kindle, PDF) | pages = 351 pp. | isbn = 9781897113684 | oclc = }} '''''The Red Wall: A Woman in the RCMP''''' is a [[non-fiction]] book, written by [[Canadian writer]] Jane Hall, first published in July 2007 by General Store Publishing. In the book, the author chronicles her personal experiences as the first woman accepted in the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] (RCMP). Hall recalls that ever since becoming a Mountie in 1977, people have asked her "What it was like"? Hall says she always avoided answering the question because she knew the story couldn't be told with a few sentences. The book's 351 pages are apparently sufficient as the book has been well received for its historical significance. Hall says of her book, "It was time to break the silence; time to acknowledge our successes and our failures. Time to move forward."General Store Publishing, [http://gsph.indelta.ca/index.php?ID=477&Lang=En ''The Red Wall''], Retrieved 11/23/2012 Hall spent eight years writing her manuscript, and another two years copy-editing her work before presenting it for publication.Open Book Toronto, December 5, 2007, [http://www.openbooktoronto.com/news/10_questions_with_jane_hall 10 Questions With Jane Hall], Home - News, Retrieved 11/23/2012 ==Awards and honours== ''The Red Wall'' received shortlist recognition for the 2008 "[[Edna Staebler Award]] for [[Creative Non-Fiction]]".Faculty of Arts, March 20, 2009, [https://archive.is/20121208134156/http://www.wlu.ca/news_detail.php?grp_id=28&nws_id=4957 The shortlist for the 2008 Edna Staebler Award], ''Wilfrid Laurier University'', Headlines (News Releases), Retrieved 11/23/2012 ==See also== *[[List of Edna Staebler Award recipients]] ==References== {{reflist}}[https://www.amazon.com/The-Red-Wall-Woman-RCMP/dp/1897113684/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1358447494&sr=8-1&keywords=the+red+wall+a+woman+in+the+rcmp Amazon, ''The Red Wall: A Woman in the RCMP''], [https://www.amazon.com/The-Red-Wall-Woman-RCMP/product-reviews/1897113684/ref=cm_cr_dp_see_all_btm?ie=UTF8&showViewpoints=1&sortBy=bySubmissionDateDescending Book Reviews], Retrieved 01/17/2013 ==External links== *Presentation by Jane Hall, July 15, 2008, [http://www.policecouncil.ca/reports/JHall08.pdf Changing the face of leadership from within; Gender differences in leadership styles], to the International Consortium for Public Safety Leadership, Retrieved 11/22/2012 {{Edna Staebler Award}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Red Wall}} [[Category:Canadian non-fiction books]] [[Category:2007 books]] [[Category:Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] {{Canada-book-stub}} {{gender-book-stub}}

'''''The Story of Modern Science''''' is a ten-volume [[book]] series by [[Henry Smith Williams]], published by Funk and Wagnalls Co. The books, published in 1923, explained in detail the current technology and scientific methods of the [[Modern Era]].
The 10 volumes include:
:I. Charting the Universe :II. Exploring the Atom :III. Analyzing the Man :IV. Conjuring with Plants :V. Juggling with Animal Life :VI. Wonder-Working by Machinery :VII. Bettering the Race of Man :VIII. Super-Engines of War :IX. Radio-Mastery of the Ether :X. Man and the Magic of Medicine

{{multiple issues| {{POV|date=October 2017}} {{too few opinions|date=October 2017}} {{weasel|date=October 2017}} }} {{italic title}} '''''The Theory of Interstellar Trade'''''Krugman, Paul (1978), [http://www.princeton.edu/~pkrugman/interstellar.pdf "The Theory of Interstellar Trade"], July 1978 is a paper written in 1978 by the [[economist]] [[Paul Krugman]]. The paper was first published in March 2010 in the journal ''[[Economic Inquiry]]''.[[Paul Krugman]]. [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1465-7295.2009.00225.x/full "The Theory of Interstellar Trade"], ''[[Economic Inquiry]]'', March 2010. He described the paper as something he wrote to cheer himself up when he was an "oppressed assistant professor" caught up in the academic [[rat race]].Paul Krugman, [https://krugman.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/03/11/economics-the-final-frontier/ "Economics: the final frontier"], ''The New York Times'', March 11, 2008 Krugman analyzed the question of
How should interest rates on goods in transit be computed when the goods travel at close to the speed of light? This is a problem because the time taken in transit will appear less to an observer traveling with the goods than to a stationary observer.
Krugman emphasized that in spite of its farcical subject matter, the economic analysis in the paper is correctly done. In his own words,
while the subject of this paper is silly, the analysis actually does make sense. This paper, then, is a serious analysis of a ridiculous subject, which is of course the opposite of what is usual in economics.
==Commentary== Responding to the paper, the economist [[Tyler Cowen]] speculated on how [[time travel]] affects [[time preference]] discounting.Tyler Cowen, [http://www.marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2008/03/the-theory-of-i.html "The theory of interstellar trade"], Marginal Revolution, March 11, 2008
My own puzzling focuses on the determinants of real interest rates, given how time dilation changes the meaning of time preference. As you approach the speed of light you move into the future relative to more stationary observers. So can you not leave a penny in a savings account, take a very rapid spaceflight, and come back to earth "many years later" as a billionaire? Hardly any time has passed for you. In essence we are abolishing time preference, or at least allowing people to lower their time preference by spending money on fuel. I believe that in such worlds the real interest rate cannot exceed the costs at which more fuel can "propel you into the future through time dilation."
Assume you have a spaceship that can approach lightspeed and thus you can make, say 1,000 years, seem like 10 years. If you can gain the [[time value of money]] 100 times faster, that effectively makes the interest rate 100x higher for you. Thus time preference is meaningless. This is a problem for economic theory. Krugman's solution is to force the interest rate to correspond to the cost of making the trip. Here is the standard compound interest formula: : FV = PV(1+i)n Fuel costs for the above trip are $X. Let us say you have $1,000 to invest and wonder whether it is worth taking a near-lightspeed voyage to increase your return 10 subjective years from now. Stay on earth: : A = $1000(1 + i)10 Take trip: : B = ($1000(1 + i)1000) – $X Krugman says that it is necessarily true that A=B, for time preference theory to stay consistent; thus it will be driven by X. In the future, given a free market, spaceship fuel costs will be the primary determinant of interest rates. The less the fuel cost, the less the interest rate, and vice versa. ==Related theories and publications== In 2004, Espen Gaarder Haug published a theory he titled "SpaceTime-Finance" in ''[[Wilmott Magazine|Wilmott]]'' magazine to show how a series of finance calculations had to be adjusted to avoid [[arbitrage]] when hypothetically traveling at very high velocities relative to other observers (traders). He illustrated how such necessary adjustments already could be measurable at the speed of the space shuttle, but also that such calculations and adjustments were of little or no practical relevance today since we all are moving at the nearly same speed relative to the enormous speed of light. In 2008, [[John Hickman (professor)|John Hickman]] at [[Berry College]] in Georgia (USA) published in the ''[[Journal of Astro Politics]]'' an article related to the political and cultural obstacles that could be related to hypothetical interstellar trade. A 2009 article explored tax implications.{{cite journal|last1=Adam|first1=Chodorow|title=Tax in the Final Frontier: A Theory of Interstellar Tax|journal=Social Science Research Network|date=8 December 2009|ssrn=1520413|accessdate=}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * Espen Gaarder Haug. "SpaceTime Finance" in the book 'Derivatives Models on Models', [[John Wiley & Sons]], 2007 * [[John Hickman (professor)|John Hickman]]. "Problems of Interplanetary and Interstellar Trade". ''Journal of Astro Politics'', Vol.6, No. 1. (January 2008). pp. 95–104. * [http://www.charteredaccountants.com.au/News-Media/Charter/Charter-articles/Economy/2013-12--Trading-with-aliens.aspx "Trading with Aliens"], ''Charter Magazine, Dec 2013'', {{DEFAULTSORT:Theory Of Interstellar Trade, The}} [[Category:1978 documents]] [[Category:Economic theories]] [[Category:Works by Paul Krugman]]

{{Infobox book | name = Theory and History | image = Theory and History, Front Cover, Ludwig von Mises.jpg | caption = First edition cover | author = [[Ludwig von Mises]]
Preface by [[Murray N. Rothbard]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | subjects = [[Philosophy]], [[Methodology]], [[History]], [[Economics]] | publisher = [[Yale University Press]], [[Ludwig von Mises Institute]] | pub_date = 1957 | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover|Hardback]] & [[Paperback]]) | pages = 384 | isbn = 978-0865975699 | oclc = 167149 }} '''''Theory and History: An Interpretation of Social and Economic Evolution''''' is a treatise by [[Austrian School|Austrian school]] economist and philosopher [[Ludwig von Mises]]. It can be thought of as a continuation in the development of the Misesian system of social science. In particular, it provides further [[epistemology|epistemological]] support for his earlier works, esp. [[Human Action]]. Most notably, Mises elaborates on [[methodological dualism]], develops the concept of [[thymology]] – a historical branch of the sciences of human action – and presents his critique of Marxist [[Dialectical materialism|materialism]]. Furthermore, Mises puts forward a theory of knowledge and value. He later explores and critically analyzes paradigms of thought like [[determinism]], [[materialism]], [[dialectic materialism]], [[historicism]], [[scientism]], [[positivism]], [[behaviorism]] and [[psychology]]. He argues that these schools of thought – some politically motivated,Mises. (1957). ''Theory and history'', pp. 26, 134. others blinded by dogmatism''id''. pp. 30, 77, 111, 247. – have committed epistemological and methodological blunders and are not conducive to a scientific understanding of human behavior. Economist [[Murray Rothbard]] considered ''Theory and History'' to be Mises's most overlooked work.''id''. pp. xi-xix == Synopsis == Mises presents the book in four parts. '''Introduction and Part One – Value:''' The first part sets the overall theme of the book with Mises introducing the concept of [[methodological dualism]]. He then expounds a theory of value that is central throughout. Regarding his view on science – as systematic body of knowledge, of both natural and social phenomena – as a means to successful action in the world, Mises argues that in order to properly understand human behavior we must attribute – as a methodological resort – [[Volition (psychology)|volition]] and [[Teleology|purpose]] to human behaviour. Mises considers this the epistemological and methodological basis of the sciences of human action. The branch that deals with the logical implications of action as such is called [[praxeology]]. '''Part Two – Determinism and Materialism:''' In the second part, Mises weighs in on the [[free will]] vs. [[determinism]] controversy and comments that the long historical debates did little to settle the problems at hand. He argues that while the natural sciences, in discovering scientific laws, must presuppose a strict regularity in the occurrence of causes and effects, i.e. determinism, such a presupposition cannot be held in the case of human action. He argues further that the social sciences must take [[thought]]s, [[idea]]s, and [[value judgment|judgments of value]] as ultimately given in the analysis of human action. Our ignorance of the origins and causes of these phenomena, Mises argues, forces us – at least for the time being – to adopt a dualistic approach. He contends that attempts to find the origins and causes of these phenomena are vain, as is the task of all varieties of materialism.''id''. p. 69. Mises then turns his attention to the doctrine of materialism, more specifically, that of Marxist dialectical materialism. '''Part Three – Epistemological Problems of History:''' The third part deals with the logical and epistemological problems of historical analysis. Mises explains the individualistic character of historical human events. He argues that the historian must ultimately face – when tracing back the causal factors behind past human action – a point at which no further reduction is possible, i.e. the ideas and actions of individuals. This, he claims, is the "ultimate given of history".''id''. pp. 183–8. In spite of the individuality of historical events, Mises still insists there are general laws of human behaviour but that they are praxeological laws, i.e. [[A priori and a posteriori|a priori]], not historical laws, i.e. [[A priori and a posteriori|a posteriori]]. However, [[historicism]], according to Mises, claimed there were no general laws – especially economic laws – of human behavior. Mises then enters into a critique of historicism. Mises also addresses the challenges of scientism in the context of social science, namely the application of positivism and behaviorism in the realm of human action. However, more noteworthy is Mises's presentation of [[thymology]], a historical branch of the sciences of human action. Mises argues that thymology is what everybody resorts to when trying to [[Verstehen|''understand'']] and anticipate the historical and future actions of their fellow men, and is particularly useful to the historian. He then expounds the scope of thymology and its relation to praxeology. '''Part Four – The Course of History:''' In the final part of his treatise, Mises dissects and critiques various speculations and interpretations of history, including a common interpretation of modern [[Western culture|Western civilization]]. He also comments on his observation regarding society's move away from [[classical liberalism]], freedom, and capitalism towards socialism and totalitarianism. Moreover, Mises notes the rising ideology of wealth and income equality and speculates on its origins. He argues that rising anti-capitalistic ideology is fostering a present trend toward the impoverishment of society. He criticizes the notion of society's inevitable "trend toward progress",''id''. pp. 367-70. and argues that the evolution of society and civilization is predicated – not on an automatic and inevitable path – but on the underlying ideology which can, at any time, change. To this point, Mises closes with some remarks on the uncertainty of the future and the neglect of ideological factors that can give rise to civilization but also stamp it out. == See also == * [[Praxeology]], the study of human action * ''[[Human Action]]'' * [[Ludwig von Mises Institute]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * [https://mises.org/library/theory-and-history-interpretation-social-and-economic-evolution Book page] at [https://www.mises.org/ Ludwig von Mises Institute] * [https://mises.org/quotes.aspx?action=source&Source=Theory%20and%20History Quotes from the book] at [https://www.mises.org/ Ludwig von Mises Institute] * [https://mises.org/system/tdf/Theory%20and%20History%20An%20Interpretation%20of%20Social%20and%20Economic%20Evolution_1.pdf?file=1&type=document The book as PDF] at [https://www.mises.org/ Ludwig von Mises Institute] * [http://oll.libertyfund.org/titles/1464 The book as HTML] at [http://oll.libertyfund.org// Online Library of Liberty] * [https://mises.org/library/theory-and-history-6 Audiobook] – read by [[John Pruden]] {{Ludwig von Mises}} [[Category:1957 books]] [[Category:Books by Ludwig von Mises]] [[Category:Classical liberalism]] [[Category:Contemporary philosophical literature]] [[Category:Philosophy books]] [[Category:Philosophy of social science]]

'''Yorick''' is an [[Interpreted language|interpreted]] [[programming language]] designed for [[numerics]], [[graph of a function|graph]] plotting, and steering large scientific simulation codes. It is quite fast due to [[Array data structure|array]] syntax, and extensible via [[C (programming language)|C]] or [[Fortran]] routines. It was created in 1996 by [[David H. Munro]] of [[Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory]].
== Features == === Indexing === Yorick is good at manipulating elements in N-dimensional arrays conveniently with its powerful syntax.
Several elements can be accessed all at once:
<source lang="console"> > x=[1,2,3,4,5,6]; > x [1,2,3,4,5,6] > x(3:6) [3,4,5,6] > x(3:6:2) [3,5] > x(6:3:-2) [6,4] </source>
;Arbitrary elements
<source lang="console"> > x=[[1,2,3],[4,5,6]] > x [[1,2,3],[4,5,6]] > x([2,1],[1,2]) [[2,1],[5,4]] > list=where(1<x) > list [2,3,4,5,6] > y=x(list) > y [2,3,4,5,6] </source>
;Pseudo-index
Like "theading" in [[Perl Data Language|PDL]] (Perl Data Language) and "broadcasting" in [[Numpy]] (Numeric extension for Python), Yorick has a mechanism to do this:
<source lang="console"> > x=[1,2,3] > x [1,2,3] > y=[[1,2,3],[4,5,6]] > y [[1,2,3],[4,5,6]] > y(-,) [[[1],[2],[3]],[[4],[5],[6]]] > x(-,) [[1],[2],[3]] > x(,-) [[1,2,3]] > x(,-)/y [[1,1,1],[0,0,0]] > y=[[1.,2,3],[4,5,6]] > x(,-)/y [[1,1,1],[0.25,0.4,0.5]] </source>
;Rubber index
".." is a rubber-index to represent zero or more dimensions of the array.
<source lang="console"> > x=[[1,2,3],[4,5,6]] > x [[1,2,3],[4,5,6]] > x(..,1) [1,2,3] > x(1,..) [1,4] > x(2,..,2) 5 </source>
"*" is a kind of rubber-index to reshape a slice(sub-array) of array to a vector.
<source lang="console"> > x(*) [1,2,3,4,5,6] </source>
;Tensor multiplication
[[Tensor]] multiplication is done as follows in Yorick:
P(,+, )*Q(, +)
means <math>\sum_{j=1}^{j=N}{P_{ijkl}Q_{mnj}}</math>
<source lang="console"> > x=[[1,2,3],[4,5,6]] > x [[1,2,3],[4,5,6]] > y=[[7,8],[9,10],[11,12]] > x(,+)*y(+,) [[39,54,69],[49,68,87],[59,82,105]] > x(+,)*y(,+) [[58,139],[64,154]] </source>
